You didnâ€™t grow up obsessed with menâ€™s fashion since you were a teenager. You didnâ€™t spend a decade watching, learning, critiquing, and fighting with people online. Don't copy TBPN

May 24, 2025

I saw someone tweet we should build the TBPN for India. As someone whoâ€™s followed TBPN from day one, let me be clear: you canâ€™t build TBPN. Itâ€™s an N-of-1 product.

This reminds me of when the â€˜Derek Guyâ€™ was blowing up on Twitter. People said: â€œIf you want to grow fast today, just do what this menswear guy is doing.â€ However, the problem is: youâ€™re not him. You didnâ€™t grow up obsessed with menâ€™s fashion since you were a teenager. You didnâ€™t spend a decade watching, learning, critiquing, and fighting with people online. You will never have his deep knowledge of menswear, his biting tone, and years of immersion in fashion.

Yes, you can mimic the TBPN format. You can recreate the delivery. You can copy the lighting, the sound effects, you can even create vibe reels. But you canâ€™t copy the taste of John Coogan and Jordi Hays. You canâ€™t fake their love of startups. Showing up every day to do 3 hour live streams. You canâ€™t manufacture the charisma or the humour or the edge.

Similarly, when the All in podcast was blowing up during the pandemic, a bunch of people tried to replicate the format. Logan Bartlett, Nikita Bier, and Zak Kukoff gave it a shot. They created the 3 Cartoon Avatars podcast. I remember half a dozen other copycats too. Unfortunately, it didnâ€™t land for any of them.

Nikitaâ€™s humor, which works brilliantly on Twitter, just didnâ€™t translate to the podcast arena. Their dynamic felt forced. The chemistry wasnâ€™t there. Consequently, the whole thing came off like a weak copy of the All in crew.

Ironically, Logan actually did become a good podcaster â€” but only after the others left. He leaned into what heâ€™s uniquely good at: his takes as a VC, his ability to ask smart questions, and his access to top tier guests willing to come and share real alpha. Thatâ€™s when his podcast clicked and it became his thing.

The truth is, just because youâ€™re good at shitposting on Twitter doesnâ€™t mean youâ€™ll be good on a podcast. Every platform amplifies different strengths. Moreover, if youâ€™re just trying to copy a format without knowing what your strengths are, youâ€™ll end up sounding like a knockoff.

Itâ€™s a common trap: seeing someone else win and thinking you can just â€œdo that.â€ However, most formats arenâ€™t plug and play. Theyâ€™re built around peopleâ€™s lived experience, tone, chemistry, and voice.

And when thatâ€™s missing, the audience feels it instantly.

I would not recommend copying TBPN. It just wouldnâ€™t work.
